Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 39197  
November 2005 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance 
Supporting the Achievement of the Millennium 
Development Goals in the Asia and Pacific Region: 
Phase II
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank

  MDG  –  millennium development goal 
  PRS  –  poverty reduction strategy 
  TA  –  technical assistance

Vice President  G. H. P. B. van der Linden, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development
Director General  B. N. Lohani, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
 
Mission leader  S. Chatterjee, Head, Poverty Unit (RSDD)

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  United  Nations  Economic  and  Social  Commission  for  Asia  and  the  Pacific 
(UNESCAP) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) jointly produced the first 
regional Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) Report for the Asia-Pacific Region in 2003 
(MDG Report I).1 The Asian Development Bank (ADB) was not formally associated with MDG 
Report I. Although ADB was invited and participated in the advisory committee, it provided no 
funding support for preparing the report. After the first regional report was published, both 
UNESCAP and UNDP expressed the feeling that ADB’s partnership with the United Nations 
(UN)  agencies  on  the  achievement  of  the  MDGs  would  strengthen  the  regional  effort  in 
furthering the MDG agenda in the region. A formal request for ADB to participate in a regional 
partnership on the MDGs was made in January 2004, and ADB formally agreed to participate in 
the tripartite partnership, through technical assistance (TA) provided over three phases between 
2004 and 2008 involving, among others, preparation of joint regional reports on MDGs in 2005 
(MDG Report II) and 2007 (MDG Report III), technical papers, and active dissemination of 
messages from these outputs to stakeholders in the region to support efforts to achieve the 
MDGs.  
 
2.  The first phase TA for $350,000 was approved on 4 November 2004. Its main output 
was  the  preparation  of  joint  MDG  Report  II  entitled  A  Future  Within  Reach:  Reshaping 
Institutions in a Region of Disparity to Meet the Millennium Development Goals in Asia and the 
Pacific. The report was launched jointly by the three partner institutions at a high-level event at 
ADB headquarters on 7 September 2005 and again at a UN General Assembly Session side 
event in New York on 13 September 2005. In addition, several technical papers on separate 
topics are being finalized as part of the TA.  
 
3.  The second phase TA is intended to build on the outputs of the first phase, further 
advancing regional efforts on achievement of the MDGs and taking steps for preparing MDG 
report III. The TA design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1) summarizes the main aspects 
of the second phase TA.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The UN  General Assembly adopted the Millennium Declaration in September 2000 
defining the MDGs and marking the overwhelming consensus of the international community at 
the beginning of the millennium to achieve a rapid reduction in poverty in all its dimensions by 
2015. Joining this global effort, ADB’s enhanced poverty reduction strategy (PRS) resulting from 
the PRS Review of 2004 strongly emphasizes the achievement of the MDGs and makes the 
attainment of the MDGs in the region ADB’s long-term objective, on the basis of which the 
overall impact of its operations will be measured. Thus, ADB’s annual report on implementation 
of the PRS, which monitors and assesses ADB’s overall development effectiveness and is a key 
element of the Managing for Development Results initiative, uses the MDGs to monitor ADB’s 
overall impact on poverty reduction in the region. 
 
5.  A global stocktaking exercise was conducted in 2005 on progress on the MDGs since 
the 2000 Declaration. The process culminated in the UN Summit Meeting of world leaders on 
14–16 September 2005 as part of the 60th Session of the UN General Assembly. The meeting 
                                                 
1 United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific and United Nations Development 
Programme. 2003. Promoting the Millennium Development Goals in Asia and the Pacific: Meeting the Challenges 
of Poverty Reduction. Bangkok. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 26 May 2005.

2   
discussed progress on the MDGs and further steps needed for their achievement, strongly 
reiterated  members’  unanimous  support  for  the  MDGs,  and  agreed  to  a  number  of  steps 
including stepping up assistance by developed countries and improved governance and other 
measures for more effective use of assistance by developing countries. However, the immediate 
focus of international attention is more on Sub-Saharan Africa where a number of measures of 
assistance are planned including debt relief for highly indebted poor countries (HIPC).3    
 
6.  The joint MDG Report II prepared by ADB/UNDP/UNESCAP was intended to draw the 
world’s attention to the magnitude of the problems faced by the Asia and Pacific region also, 
which faces deprivations in many cases much larger in absolute numbers than those of Sub-
Saharan Africa; and to galvanize regional and country efforts toward achieving the MDGs.4 
Looking at the latest available data, the report notes that despite the region’s rapid progress on 
several MDGs, not all countries are making sufficient progress and none are currently on track 
to meet all the goals. Although the region has made dramatic progress on the income poverty 
target, its achievements on several of the nonincome poverty-related MDGs—particularly infant 
and child mortality, maternal mortality, rural water supply, and enrollment in primary education—
have not been satisfactory. The report also identifies 19 countries of greatest concern becasue 
of insufficient progress on these indicators. Apart from focusing attention on the most urgent 
tasks and the countries lagging most behind and need to be supported, the report emphasizes 
the need to reshape institutions to better address service delivery for achieving the MDGs at the 
national and local government levels; and also the need for strengthening regional cooperation 
institutions for achieving the MDGs.   
 
7.  The two regional reports along with the series of technical papers5 on different aspects 
of the MDGs that are part of the joint partnership between ADB, UNDP and UNESCAP will help 
focus global attention on the regional issues facing attainment of the MDGs as well as help 
galvanize national and regional efforts. Toward that end, the second report was launched 
through two high-level events in September 2005: at ADB headquarters in Manila, and as a side 
event just prior to the UN Summit Meeting in New York. In his address at the UN Summit 
meeting,6 the ADB President also highlighted the regional challenges facing the achievement of 
the MDGs. A number of other notable events that have been supported by ADB building up to 
the Summit meeting included a high-level regional conference in Tokyo, Japan, on the health-
related  MDGs  in  June  2005;  and  a  ministerial-level  meeting  in  August  2005  in  Jakarta, 
Indonesia,  which  adopted  a  declaration  by  countries  and  stakeholders  in  the  region  for 
accelerating progress on the MDGs.7   
 
8.  However, to keep up the momentum that has been generated on the MDGs beyond 
2005, considerable effort will be needed so that all stakeholders continue to strive toward 
achieving  the  MDGs  in  the  remaining  years  to  2015.    The  efforts  will  require  continuing 
dissemination activities on the report and its proposed 2006 update and the technical papers 
that need to be prepared on the areas of concern identified in the second regional report, and

joint dialogue by ADB and the UN agencies with governments of the region and stakeholders on 
issues relating to attainment of the MDGs.   
 
9.  Continued  focused  work  on  special  issues  arising  in  tackling  the  areas  of  concern 
identified in the report is also necessary. For example, the health indicators in the region are 
particularly worrisome. Health improvements require complex interventions simultaneously in 
several areas apart from augmented investments in primary health care.8 The issues need to be 
studied, solutions for consideration offered, and good practices that have worked elsewhere 
highlighted. The technical paper series that has begun with MDG Report II will therefore need to 
be continued.   
 
10.  The MDG Report II also identified serious data deficiencies on the MDGs.  While a major 
effort was made in the period October 2003-April 2005 prior to preparing MDG Report II to fill 
the gaps in data, and 33% more data values than available previously were obtained, many 
indicators are still not available for all countries or areas where they would be relevant.9 Thus 
improving the data set is a high-priority activity and needs to be urgently addressed so that the 
regional MDG report III targeted for preparation in 2007 can more accurately depict progress.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA’s main goal is to establish a better basis for tracking progress on the MDGs by 
stakeholders and make operationally relevant analysis available to them, particularly in the 
sectors of concern and countries of the Asia and Pacific region identified in MDG Report II as 
currently at risk of not achieving the MDGs. It is envisaged that regional MDG reports, and the 
background and supporting technical papers will be properly disseminated, raise awareness, 
lead to improved policies and institutions, and generate increased resources and capacities for 
attaining the MDGs.  
 
12.  The main outputs of the phase II TA are (i) improved data on MDGs for preparing the 
third MDG report (scheduled for 2007); (ii) a regional MDG report update in 2006 and a series of 
operationally relevant technical papers, which will also help in preparing the third MDG report; 
and (iii) dissemination of MDG Report II and its proposed update and technical papers to 
appropriate audiences in developing member countries (DMCs) so that greater awareness is 
created,  and  necessary  action  initiated  by  governments  and  all  stakeholders  for  MDG 
attainment.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  ADB, UNDP, and UNESCAP will closely monitor the outputs and outcomes (paras. 16–
17). The data improvement and gap-filling activity will be conducted mainly by UNESCAP in 
consultation with UNDP and ADB. The MDG report update will be prepared by UNESCAP with 
the  support  of  UNDP  and  ADB.  The  technical  papers  will  be  contributed  by  all  three 
                                                 
8 The complexity of the interventions may be seen, as a special example, in the ADB case study on health prepared 
for the Shanghai Upscaling Conference, which can be accessed at http://www.adb.org/Documents/Papers/Scaling-
Up/Health-Sector/default.asp  
9 See MDG Report-II appendix on data availability. Indicators 18, 38, 39, 42, 43, and 46 do not have any data values 
for any regional member and associate member of UNESCAP. The data series available ranged from 51 
(Indonesia) to 12 (American Samoa).  Even where data series are available, many have just one data point, which 
cannot be used to estimate trends.

4   
organizations. Dissemination of the documents and policy dialogue will be conducted by all 
three agencies and coordinated through the ADB resident missions and UNDP country offices. 
An effective dissemination plan will be developed for this purpose.  
 
14.  It is envisaged that phase II will tentatively cover the following areas:  
(i)  Improving data coverage and quality. The major emphasis in phase II will be 
on 3 different areas as elaborated in Appendix 2, namely (a) comprehensive 
updating of data sets and filling in of missing data including using alternative 
national  data  series  or  those  from  other  agencies  that  are  collected 
systematically, if they are found reliable; (b) disaggregating data, to the extent 
feasible, geographically as well as by gender, ethnic group, religious group, age, 
or  other  social-economic  dimensions  to  understand  where  deprivations  are 
highest and to recommend remedial measures; and (c)  developing an MDG 
policy database containing a classification of policy measures by type of action 
and information on target groups and number of beneficiaries, as well as on 
expenditure, to better understand the impact of policies on targets and goals.  In 
addition, studies are planned on two important areas concerning data-related 
matters,  namely,  testing  the  usefulness  of  certain  indicators  for  monitoring 
targets and goals with a view to improving/replacing them; and studying the 
linkages, complementarities, and trade-offs between different targets to focus 
action most efficiently to achieve the MDGs. The overall process is expected to 
contribute to developing a strengthened partnership between UN agencies, ADB, 
DMCs, and stakeholders working to strengthen MDG-related data at the regional 
level.  
(ii)  MDG report update 2006 and technical studies.  To inform regional policy 
makers and other stakeholders, an update of the regional MDG report based on 
updated data collected and including annual highlights and developments will be 
prepared in 2006. In addition, a number of detailed studies on aspects of concern 
[(i) (b)] as well as those identified by MDG Report II including in areas of service 
delivery and regional cooperation, exploring greater market-driven solutions to 
MDG attainment, and other areas considered important by the three agencies will 
be  prepared  and  jointly  published.  The  studies  will  be  designed  to  be  of 
operational relevance to policy makers and technical experts in the concerned 
field and provide ideas on changes necessary to tackle problems encountered. 
The studies and the findings from them will help also in developing the third joint 
MDG report scheduled for 2007. 
 
(iii)  Dissemination. To ensure that policy makers in the region, aid sources, and 
other stakeholders actually deliberate the issues highlighted in the two MDG 
regional reports and the technical paper series, the three agencies have drawn 
up a dissemination program. The program involves subregional launches and 
side  events  of  MDG  report  II  and  technical  papers,  national  advocacy  and 
communication  events,  and  MDG  web-based  dissemination  and  networking. 
Dissemination material for various types of media will be prepared, with the help 
of ADB resident missions and UNDP country offices.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  Phase II has a total cost of $1,300,000, of which ADB would fund $325,000.  Of this ADB 
funding, $190,000 will be transferred to UNESCAP for its part of implementation broadly defined 
in para. 13; while $135,000 will be retained by ADB for ADB-led activities. A total of $975,000 
will be funded by UNESCAP and UNDP. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3.       
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The three-phase TA project is an important collaborative exercise between ADB, UNDP, 
and UNESCAP, which have all given their financial and staff resource commitments to ensure 
quality outputs. A formal memorandum of understanding (MOU) was concluded with UNESCAP 
and UNDP for phase I, defining the roles and responsibilities of the partner agencies to ensure 
smooth implementation of the project. This arrangement will continue for phase II although a 
separate MOU will be prepared addressing the specific outputs of this phase. ADB will be the 
Executing  Agency  for  the  TA  to  be  implemented  by  the  Poverty  Unit  of  Regional  and 
Sustainable Development Department, which will coordinate an interdepartmental effort for the 
purpose.  
 
17.  A high-level steering committee comprising the ADB Vice President for Knowledge 
Management  and  Sustainable  Development,  UNESCAP  Executive  Secretary,  and  UNDP 
Assistant Administrator for East Asia and the Pacific was set up to provide overall guidance for 
the project. A working group consisting of representatives at the staff level from the three 
organizations will coordinate the preparation and ensure the quality and timely delivery of 
outputs.  
 
18.  The phase II TA will engage 11 person-months of consulting services (6 person-
months international, and 5 domestic) for the TA activities directly undertaken by ADB. The 
consultants to be hired by ADB will be development specialists with experience in the area of 
MDGs (Appendix 4). The consultants will be engaged individually in accordance with ADB’s  
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants. 
 
19.  This phase is part of the TA cluster that will run for 4 years altogether in three phases of 
15 months each. The main purpose of phase I was to support the preparation of MDG Report II 
and technical papers. Phase I began on 1 October 2004 and is expected to be completed at the 
end of 2005 (15 months).  Phase II will begin on 1 January 2006 and continue until 31 March 
2007 (15 months). Phase III will focus mainly on MDG report III and its dissemination.  However, 
the content of phase III will be determined based on the needs and priorities indicated by the 
steering committee. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $325,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting the Achievement of the Millennium Development Goals in the Asia and Pacific 
Region: Phase II, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 2 
DATA DEVELOPMENT SUPPORT FOR MDG III 
 
1.  The recently published joint second regional Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 
report—A Future Within Reach: Reshaping Institutions in a Region of Disparities to Meet the 
Millennium  Development  Goals  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific—has  pointed  to  significant  data 
deficiencies. To improve the data on MDGs for MDG report III, three main data-related issues 
need to be addressed.   
 
2.  Comprehensive  Data  Updating  and  Gap  Filling.  Data  in  the  United  Nations 
Department of Economics and Social Affairs (UNDESA) database, which is the primary source 
of MDG-related data, is often outdated. For example, the latest (1999) value for the girls-to-boys 
ratio in primary education in Afghanistan is 0.08. The 1990 value for this indicator was 0.55. 
MDG Report II therefore concludes that Afghanistan is regressing from gender parity in primary 
education. A closer look at the actual current situation, however, suggests that the Government 
of Afghanistan, with assistance from the international community, is addressing the issue with 
the urgency it deserves. The gender parity ratio is now around 0.54 at all levels of education; 
the ratio for the primary level probably has surpassed the 1990 value. Rather than regressing, 
Afghanistan, on the present trend, is likely to reach the target by 2015. To increase its relevance, 
a mechanism is needed to update the UNDESA database with the latest information available at 
the national level. Close contact with national statistics offices will be maintained and their 
cooperation sought for this purpose. Use will also be made of work in this area being done 
through  other  initiatives  such  as  the  Partnership  in  Development  for  Statistics  in  the  21st 
Century (PARIS21). In this respect, the ADB country offices, the UN country teams, and the 
Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC) can also play a key role in providing the necessary 
metadata and in ensuring that the new data are reliable. The updated information can be 
disseminated on a regular basis to the public ahead of and independent from the release of 
forthcoming regional MDG reports.  
 
3.  Disaggregated Data.  The need for geographically disaggregated data to understand 
trends at subnational levels has assumed importance. A more fundamental question is what 
disparities really matter. Are they indeed geographical in nature, or do ethnic, religious, gender, 
age or other social-economic dimensions matter more? To establish the key factors in the MDG 
performance of different social-economic groups, disaggregated data reflecting attainments by 
such  groups  will  be  needed.  Household-level  information  (micro  data)  and  use  of  special 
statistical techniques for small area estimation1 may be required. To this end, use will be made 
of the regional repository of household surveys that ADB (Economics and Research Department) 
is developing and which is expected to be functional by 2006.   
 
4.  MDG  Policy  Database.    An  important  question  is  what  determines  the  score  of 
countries on the specific targets/goals and how to explain the differences between them. During 
the drafting of MDG Report II, attempts were made to explain the net primary enrollment rate 
and under-5 mortality through panel regression models. Although interesting preliminary insights 
were obtained, difficulties in data and model specification prevented the derivation of robust 
conclusions. Information on the policy measures that affect (directly or indirectly) the MDG 
performance  of  each  country  was  insufficient.  An  MDG  policy  database  containing  a 
                                                 
1 The Economics and Research Department has acquired material on some of these areas through earlier regional 
technical assistance work, which will be utilized.

Appendix 2  9
classification of measures by type of action and information on target groups and number of 
beneficiaries, as well as on expenditure, should be developed.  
 
5.  Special Studies.  In addition, data-related studies are also important. An important 
issue is the apparent difference in quality between indicators that relate to a given target or goal. 
Goal 1—eradicate extreme poverty and hunger—for example, consists of two targets and five 
indicators. Preliminary results of ongoing research at the secretariat of the United Nations 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific indicate that four of the indicators 
correlate strongly with the underlying latent construct poverty and hunger, but that the fifth, the 
proportion of population below minimum level of dietary energy consumption, does not. This 
finding is not surprising: the four relevant indicators are directly measured at the household level, 
but the dietary intake indicator is the balance of national food production, apparent consumption, 
trade, and change in stocks. The implication of a lack of correlation between an indicator and 
the underlying construct—i.e., target or goal—that it intends to measure is that the indicator is 
redundant for monitoring purposes, and that the time and effort to be spent on it could be better 
utilized elsewhere. A clearer focus on the indicators that really matter is therefore urgently 
needed. 
 
6.  Another  area  worth  investigating  is  the  possible  complementarities  and  trade-offs 
between different targets. MDG Report II finds evidence, for example, that improved access to 
clean water leads to lower child mortality rates. Investment in and expenditure on potable water 
sources therefore contribute not only to the achievement of goal 7, but also of goal 4. On the 
other hand, it is also possible that a reallocation of resources from one target or goal to another 
will  have  no  effect  on  the  overall  progress  toward  the  MDGs.  Insight  into  the  issue  of 
complementarity versus substitution is crucial for decisions on optimal allocation of resources.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 11 person-months of consulting services (6 
person-months international, and 5 domestic) for the TA activities to be undertaken directly by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB).  
 
A.  MDG Specialist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
2.  The MDG specialist will be an expert on development, particularly poverty reduction and 
the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs); have considerable field experience working on 
MDG-related areas and issues; and have contributed to international journals in those areas.  
The specialist will support the preparation of technical papers on issues that are crucial for 
attaining the MDGs, particularly issues confronting poorly performing countries and sectors. The 
consultant will also contribute to and support the work of the Poverty Unit of the Regional and 
Sustainable  Development  Department  in  providing  resources  for  dissemination  activities 
undertaken  jointly  by  ADB,  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP)  and  United 
Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (UNESCAP).  Specifically 
the work will involve the following: 
(i)  In close coordination with UNESCAP, UNDP, and ADB staff, prepare technical 
papers  of  about  20  pages  long  (with  additional  pages  for  appendixes)  that 
analyze specific issues of importance concerning MDG achievement and provide 
expert opinion and advice for the use of governments.  
(ii)  Review concept notes and technical papers prepared by other agencies and give 
comprehensive comments to improve the quality of the final documents. 
(iii)  Participate in workshops and seminars undertaken as part of the dissemination 
activities  for  MDG  reports  I  and  II  and  other  technical  papers,  and  act  as 
resource person if necessary. 
 
B.  MDG Expert (domestic, 5 person-months) 
 
3.  The  MDG  expert  will  have  professional  experience  in  development,  including  field 
experience, in the areas of poverty reduction and MDGs; considerable experience with working 
on MDG-related issues; and contributions in the areas in internationally reputed publications. 
The specific tasks follow: 
(i)  Support the work of the international consultant in all assigned tasks, particularly 
with respect to data gathering and analysis.  
(ii)  Assist the international consultant in preparing technical papers that analyze 
specific issues of importance concerning MDG achievement and provide expert 
opinion and advice for the use of governments.  
(iii)  Support the international consultant in reviewing concept notes and technical 
papers  prepared  by  other  agencies  and providing  comments  to  improve  the 
quality of the final documents. 
(iv)  Help organize workshops and seminars as part of the dissemination activities for 
MDG  Reports  I  and  II  and  other  technical  papers;  including  preparation  of 
dissemination material. 
(v)  Support web-based dissemination by helping in populating ADB poverty website.
